data.title: 10 Who Make a Difference in St. Johns County: Susan Parker connects St. Augustine’s past and present
authors: Margo Pope, Record correspondent, St. Augustine Record
data.meta_description: For almost 25 years, Susan Richbourg Parker has enlightened St. Augustine Record readers about people, events and places that have shaped St. Johns County’s centuries of history. \n\n Her Sunday column…
data.text:
For almost 25 years, Susan Richbourg Parker has enlightened St. Augustine Record readers about people, events and places that have shaped St. Johns County’s centuries of history.

Her Sunday column, “The Oldest City,” is a fitting commentary for Parker, who describes herself as growing up in St. Augustine “surrounded by vestiges of centuries of history.”

Parker, who holds a doctorate in history from the University of Florida, is a self-employed research, writer and editor of historic projects.

The column started in 1996, Parker said in a recent interview as one of The St. Augustine Record’s 2019 10 Who Make a Difference in St. Johns County.

“I was working for the Preservation Board here and (Editor) Jim Sutton came to see me and said The Record was interested in putting a rail (on the left-hand column) the front page. He wanted me to give reporters information about St. Augustine history, not something you would typically find in history books. As we talked, I told him it was much easier for me to write it than to give it to someone else. He wanted 200 words at the start. When they moved it inside, it now averages 600-700 words.”

She continues to write the column because people show an interest in it. A few years ago, she met a woman at a party.

“She had lived here three years, and the columns made her feel like she had lived here longer. … She knew the (back) stories about St. Augustine,” Parker said.

Among her regular readers is longtime friend and colleague, Kathleen Deagan, an internationally recognized archaeologist who has been digging up St. Augustine’s past since the 1970s.

The columns, Deagan said, are “remarkable in the way she connects current events to the comparable events in the past. And it reaches so many people (me included) who wouldn’t ordinarily have access to the documentary information that Susan shares. It really heightens everyone’s awareness of and pride in our town.”

Another major contribution, Deagan said, was Parker’s nine years as executive director of the St. Augustine Historical Society. She said Parker increased its visibility, raised the standards for El Escibano, the Society’s annual history journal, and secured grants to improve the Society’s physical plant and its research library.

Several objectives and motivating influences drive Parker.

First, curiosity.

“If you are not curious, you don’t pay a lot of attention to anything going on in life,” she said.

Then, the past.

“History is all around us,” she said.

And while every place has history, St. Augustine lives it daily.

“It is the economic engine for the community,” she said. “People come here for the history. It employs many people. It pays the bills.”

A knack for ‘historical connections’

Parker originally wanted to pursue a career overseas but that did not happen. She joined the Historic St. Augustine Preservation Board in 1987 as a volunteer researcher under Dr. Amy Bushnell, then research historian. Bushnell is adjunct Associate Professor, Department of History at Brown University and Researcher in Residence, The John Carter Brown Library.

Bushnell spoke to a woman’s group in the living history museum, San Agustin Antiguo.

“I invited the women to help in the research library,” she said. “Susan Parker introduced herself to me as a former Spanish teacher who did title searches for her husband, a real estate lawyer. I told her that she would be a real asset to the Library, and that I only wished it were possible to pay her.”

Parker volunteered, and later the preservation board received an Institute of Museum Services grant to catalog the research library according to the Library of Congress system.

“Susan went on the payroll,” Bushnell said.

Parker said Bushnell was her first mentor. She suggested that Parker pursue a doctorate.

Bushnell said, “She had already shown that she was good at research; it now became evident that she also had an aptitude for historical connections.”

In addition to Bushnell’s mentoring, Parker credits Deagan’s influence.

“It was not a mentee-mentor relationship,” she said. “I admire the way Kathy does her research and presents it. I know I can rely on her research.”

When Parker was at the preservation board as its historian, the late Luis Arana, longtime historian of the Castillo de San Marcos, was a strong resource for his knowledge of the military history and the social history of soldiers living in the city, and of the inner workings of government agencies.

The late Michael Gannon, historian and author, guided Parker’s dissertation and provided encouragement and expertise on St. Augustine and Florida’s early Spanish history and the Florida missions period over Parker’s career.

A reach beyond the city

James Cusick Jr., curator of the P.K. Yonge Library of Florida History, said Parker’s presence reaches beyond St. Augustine.

She designed and implemented the teacher workshops that the Florida Humanities Council held each summer in St. Augustine from 2004 to 2014.

“Teachers took back to their classrooms Susan's talks on how St. Augustine came to be founded, the importance of the sea to life in town, and an understanding of daily life in colonial times,” he said.

She was also a principal scholar on the PBS program “The Secrets of Spanish Florida,” helping people understand the history of colonial women and families through records such as church documents, court cases and wills, Cusick said.

Parker is invited to present papers at national and international conferences, is a featured source in newspapers, on radio and television.

In January, she will speak on early women property owners to the American Historical Association’s international conference in New York City.

She was interviewed extensively regionally and nationally on St. Augustine’s history during the city’s 450th anniversary celebration in 2015.

Among those interviews was an hour-long talk show on the Sirius XM Trucking Channel program about St. Augustine and the Old Spanish Trail that went from here to California.

Parker’s recent major project was editor of the St. Augustine Historical Society’s second history book, “The Oldest City”. The book is a collection of chapters about the city’s history written by several authors, including Parker. The first book was published in 1983.

“We know so much more about the city’s history now than we did 30 years ago,” she said.

The book includes the impact of Native Americans and the city’s modern civil rights struggles.

With a Parker’s commitment to history, it’s obvious that her legacy is rooted in St. Augustine’s past. But, there’s a twist.

“People get down and depressed about what’s happening today,” she said. “I want them to see the big picture, that in St. Augustine’s long history there were also times when people were down and depressed, but the city’s still here.

“I want to put faces on the ordinary people who lived here, whose names are written in the parish records.”

Parker, as her biographical information attests, makes it her business to be part of the community at large.

Here’s her advice from experience:

“Be willing to go through some of the tedium to make the organization (or activity) work. It sounds boring, but somebody has to do it. Nobody wants to do the tedium. They want to do only the high-profile things.”

Parker has writing projects under way but isn’t sharing them.

As her mentor Gannon often said, “I don’t talk about them (in process) or I’ll never get them done.”

How long have you been in our community? Almost all my life.

Family:

Children, Christopher Parker, Chapel Hill; Amanda Parker Struckhoff, New Orleans; Robert Parker, St. Augustine; and four granddaughters. Both her parents moved to St. Augustine as toddlers, so they grew up in St. Augustine. Her brother is deceased.

Occupation:

Currently an independent consultant for historical projects, exhibits, media productions and preservation projects.

Executive director of St. Augustine Historical Society 2007-2016; Region Preservation consultant for State Historic Preservation Office, 2002-2007; Historian for State Historic St. Augustine Preservation Board, 1987-1997. Adjunct or visiting professor at University of North Florida, University of South Florida, University of Florida. Director of research for the PBS documentary about colonial St. Augustine, Secrets of Spanish La Florida (Secrets of the Dead PBS series), first aired 2017. First chair of St. Johns County Historic Resources Review Board, 2000, a County Commission-created advisory board.

Recent publications:

Editor, “Oldest City: The History of Saint Augustine,” a book published by The Saint Augustine Historical Society, 2019.

Wrote chapters in the following books: “The Yamasee Indians: from Florida to South Carolina,” 2018; “The Tulane European and Civil Law Forum,” 2017; “Signposts: New Directions in Southern Legal History,” 2013.

Wrote scripts for three walking tours of St. Augustine for the Florida Humanities Council self-guided app, Florida Stories.

Civic, community, professional involvement:

Rotary Club of St. Augustine Board of Directors, current; One of the founding directors of Ft. Mose Historical Society; Board of Trustees, St. Augustine Historical Society, 1992-1998; 1999-2005, president, 2000 and 2004; numerous state and national professional organizations. St. Johns County Historic Resources Review Board, first chairperson, 2000; City of St. Augustine, Confederate Monument Contextualization Committee, 2018; Committee on Women, Southern Historical Association, 2009-2012.

Education:

Ph.D. in Colonial U.S. history, University of Florida.

Minor field: Colonial Latin America. Outside minor field: Anthropology

Dissertation: “The Second Century of Settlement in Spanish St. Augustine, 1670-1763,” directed by Michael V. Gannon, Ph.D.

About Susan Parker
